awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Time-Resolved, Image-Intensified Camera for the Spatial Imaging of Quantum-Entangled Photons
awd_abstract_narration:
Imaging with cameras has transformed science and society.  Modern cameras often record huge numbers of photons, the quantum-particles of light, with arrays of electronic detectors.  This research project will investigate new applications for images that are carried by a small number of individual photons. A state-of-the-art camera will be acquired to study images formed with single photons. This will open new possibilities for studying how imaging can be accomplished in ways that take advantage of quantum aspects of photons, such as entanglement. This team will explore how new imaging methods can lead to a deeper understanding of light and pave the way to developing new quantum technologies.   The camera will also enable undergraduates to do research on quantum optics phenomena, such as "ghost imaging", and this will improve their education on the fundamentals of quantum physics.


Spatial modes of light are the basic components of images. The goal of this research is to image the spatial modes of single photons that are quantum entangled with other photons, and with other degrees of freedom, such as polarization. The image-intensified camera will enable acquiring the images of photons that are not possible with conventional cameras due to shortcomings in their triggering technology. This team will investigate using the camera to characterize the quantum state of the light in ways that are alternative to current methods. This team will also investigate the images carried by photons through their entanglement, and they will investigate high-dimensional hyper-entanglement of light. The camera will help undergraduates to do research in quantum optics with entangled photons, and this will improve students' understanding of quantum entanglement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this grant was to acquire a specialized camera. It was purchased to investigate a fundamental aspect of light: that while it is known to consist of photons, these photons can carry an image. This has already been demonstrated, in part by our previous research. A process that has been of much interest and research involves the creation of two photons out of one. This process, known as spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC), has also been used to prepare the two photons in an entangled state. Entanglement is a fundamental phenomenon that is the basis of many fundamental and applied studies that use light and matter to store and transmit information, all part of a new field known as quantum information.

Our goal is to study photon pairs created by SPDC and prepare them in an entangled state of images. This means that the image that we measure in one photon depends on the image that is measured on the other photon. The camera will be used to obtain the image of individual photons. This outcome requires a camera that can detect individual photons, but only those who have partners created by SPDC. Thus, the challenge is to manipulate detections and electronics to record photon's images. The intellectual merit of the research is that correlated photon images can lead us to understand light in a deeper sense, and these finding can be used in novel technologies such as imaging with much higher resolution and selectivity; and in communications with a greater number of channels or bandwidth that is presently available.

In the short time since its purchase, and with a long but temporary suspension of in-person laboratory activities due to the pandemic, we have only been able to get preliminary results. There are no new scientific findings to report, as the work is still ongoing. We have been succesful in setting up a laboratory apparatus that involves the production of entangled photons by SPDC and the incorporation of the purchased camera into the setup. We have also achieved making image detections of photons that are correlated to a partner photon. Thus, we have been successful in moving the project past the initial stages. Now that the basic system is operational we are optimistic that we can carry the proposed studies and discover novel phenomena.

This research has involved three undergraduates. Two of them who already graduated with a B.A. degree from Colgate University are presently pursuing a Ph.D in physics. A third student, who has not yet graduated, also has career plans to continue her studies toward a higher degree. The project has already been successful in exposing students to scientific endeavours and in making contibutions to their career plans.

Modified by: Enrique J Galvez
